measured_by: 7-point Likert scale (-3 = very inaccurate to +3 = very accurate)
justification: "Participants evaluated what they thought the accuracy of the prediction was on a scale from -3 (very inaccurate) to 3 (very accurate)."

measured_by: 7-point Likert scale (-3 = very unlikely to +3 = very likely)
justification: "Participants responded to two questions ... on how likely they would have been to use the prediction as their own (-3 very unlikely to 3 very likely)."

topic_or_construct: Perceived effort exerted by prediction provider
measured_by: 1–7 Likert scale (1 = little effort to 7 = much effort)
justification: "Participants were asked: 'How much effort did your colleague [StatCast] exert to come to this prediction?'. They could answer on a 1 (Little effort) to 7 (Much effort) scale."
"Participants were asked how difficult they thought making predictions was for humans/algorithms: ... Participants could either select 'easy' or 'difficult'."

measured_by: 7-point Likert scale (-3 = not at all to +3 = very much)
justification: "For each match, participants were asked: 'How persuasive do you think is StatCast's prediction?' ranging from -3 (Not at all) to 3 (Very much)."

measured_by: 4-item agreement scale (-3 to +3) averaged into composite
justification: "Participants' familiarity ... by presenting them with four statements for which they had to indicate their agreement from -3 (Completely disagree) to 3 (Completely agree). Cronbach's alpha was very high at .94 so we made one composite measure by averaging the results."

measured_by: 7-point Likert scale (-3 = very unlikely to +3 = very likely)
justification: "The main dependent variable ... read: 'Given StatCast's response time, how likely are you to disregard its prediction and consult a colleague instead' ranging from -3 (very unlikely) to 3 (very likely)."
